En air route Canton to Shanghai
January 5 1936.
б. чл,
Dear
Family:
It has been lo these
many moons
since you have been regaled or
bedeviled with any news letter
concerning
the peregrinations of the
writer but now I am on the
again and can write -
time bound
from Canton to
My time has
and Manila, mostly at the latter.
to Shanghai since leaving
there on Sept.
three
trips from Manila
across the
turbulent China Sea which is
English Channel only it is 700 miles
steamships which I have
traveled on lately might just as
have closed down
the cuisine
department and redecorated
dining salon.
On one trip Dec. 9th and 10th I was
the only passenger
apparently who saw anything
but the ceiling
of his or her stateroom.
When I went down to dinner
there wasn't another
passenger list of 40 so I dined
state complete with orchestra.
You would all like Macau.
It is an old Portuguese settlement
located about 40 miles west of Hongkong.
It was
course
who were
the first
to discover &
trade
the Portuguese of
route
to
China
via the
Prior to the operation of
the old Portuguese
sailing ships all
of
the silk,
tea,
spices,
etc.
of
China
moved
Europe by
the Marco
Polo or other overland caravan routes
which were often interrupted
then as now by
civil
as sourbances
Portuguese
traders
or wars along the way.
The first
settled at a
south
of Shanghai
but
point on
the China Coast near Ningpo
such was
the cruelty of their expoitation
that
the
peaceful,
defenseless
Chinese finally couldn't
"take it" any
longer with
the result that
they
"swarmed"
and
massacred the
entire
Por tugue se
Colony.
The Portuguese
then looked
around for some loc-
ation
with a good harbor
capable
of being better defended.
The y
selected &
small peninsula south of the Pearl River important trade
route
to
Canton
and
settled
there in
1557.
Macau soon
became the
focal
poift
for

doors

The
and

closed its
little Colony continued
and its residents prospered until
the
establishment of Hongkong.
The latter point was
tant
demands
for
the
given
to
England
by
China in
respouse
to insis-
protection
of English citizens.
Other nations
may
adopt a conciliatory
attitude
and
criticise
their nationals
for
straying off the reservation
but the
British have
way of letting
everyone
know
that
there is no open season on
Englishmen.
The
Chinese
au
the
time were
highly
gleeful
over
the way
they had put it over on
English - they had
driven
John Bull out
of
Canton
and had
given
him
a barren rock
off
The
the
forbidding coast
to
the
north of
the estuary of
the
Pearl
Ri ver.
English of course
transformed Hongkong into
one of
the
finest ports
ities for modern large
in
the
world which with its
unequalled
facil-
draft
ships
soon
began
to get away
all
the
business from
Canton
and Macau neither of which
could offer
proper
harbor
facilities
for
the modern large ships which began to replace
the
old
sailing
ships and
big sea-going
junks.
Today Hongkong -
much to
the chagrin
the
of China
is
the
great
port of call
for
East.
There cargoes are
trans-shipped
to
the
seven seas.
Macau is
still an
important
point
Chinese
junks - thousands of them
are
coming and
going
all
the
time with
their picturesque
sails
of straw
matting or patched
canvas.
All
these
junks
plying
11
and
around
Macau
are heavily armed
(against pirates or
operation as
such)
with old fashioned cannons.
Most of
the
sea-going
ones have
two
guns
fore and two aft.
The cannons
of
the
muzzle
loading
type
used during the War of 1812
with
a hole at the
back end for a fuse.

Page 2.
God knows what the Chinese load them with - probably for the most part
with the
off-fall of Fords - bolts,
screws,
washers,
bits of rusty iron,
etc.
I imagine if you got in the way of a
broadside and survived with
a few
scratches you would die of lockjaw within 2 hours.
Macao is sometimes referred to as the wickedest city in the
There you can buy opium,
need one from "white" slavers, or you can gamble at
main street as saloons used to be in Madison, Illinois.
gambling houses,
have signs written in Chinese, Portuguese and many
in English "First Class Gambling House."
The only foreign style Hotel is the Riviera which has about
rooms - a few with bath but none with heat and when we first
there (I went with C. S. Russell, P.A.A. Construction Engineer)
bitterly cold.
The kind of cola
that you encounter only in
or other tropical climates - a raw penetrating cold which you
can escape only by going to
We bought
an oil stove and rented
an electric heater and with both operating at wide open throttle we
managed to keep one room (our office) fairly comfortable using the
room to sleep in.
Macau is the cleanest city I have ever seen - even the
Chinese districts are clean.
Every scrap of paper
cigarettes butt
picked up or brushed away.
The streets are well paved with trees
lining both sides.
Houses are neat and clean built of brick or stone
with tile roofs.
They are mostly painted in shades of pastel pink,
blue,
green or yellow.
though a bit of old
Europe had been
lifted up and put down on the China
Most of the inhabitants are
Chinese - population of 85,000 with only 3000 Portuguese.
We were en-
tertained by
the whole American community consisting of five.
Mr. and
Mrs. Barrett, her sister (from Le Roy, N. Y.) and Mr. and Mrs. Servier.
The men are engineers in charge of the construction of a new water works
project for the Colony•
You have probably seen news reels and read about the first
arrival of the China Clipper at Manila.
Therefore I won't comment on
that event other than to say that it was thrilling and that after work-
ing for three years
some of the smaller factors involved in
successful completion of the trans-Pacific flight I naturally got a
out of seeing that first plane land on the waters of Manila
We all had Christmas Eve together at Manila and then on
Christmas Day I had
to start back to Macau leaving the family in Manila.
Stayed at Macao until New Years Eve which we (Russell and I)
celebrated
going to a movie "Broadway Melody",
having a whiskey soda at the
Vittoria night club to welcome the New Year and then I
through
firecrackers smoke to the
wharf where I took the
for Hongkong
to sleep on a cot without springs,
a concrete pillow
and hope that the
Indian guard on board
would do
their duty if any
pirates put in an appearance.
At Canton
one of my Chinese friends gave me a snake dinner
prepared by
the Number l snake chef of Canton.
The party of ten ate
20 snakes and as I
ate more than my
share it will be
clear that I
"Boscoed" at least two.
undoubtedly heard that snakes taste
like chicken - that's true -
but the snake wine was not so good.
wine tasted like corn liquor of a poor quality flavored with
quinine.
However I managed to "gombey"
(bottoms up to you) four or five small
cupsfull much to the gratification of my host and t intense discom-
of my almost rebellious

Page 3.
Today - Sunday, Jan. 4th we started for Shanghai at 6:30
run into a heavy fog on the
China coast at infamous Bias Bay and had
to
turn back.
Ne waited at Canton for more
favorable weather and now
as I write we are approaching Wenchow 260 miles south of Shanghai
where on
night.
account of
approaching
darkness we shall
to spend the
Monday Jan. 5th.
Enroute Shanghai.
Wenchow is a city of
400,000 with no foreigners - not even a missionary.
The only trans-
portation is furnished by rickshas and there are few of
natives have widened or rather built two streets and soon no doubt
there will be automobiles on those.
"streets" so called
not over four feet wide and your ricksha puller
struggles
accompaniment of many shouts at scurrying chilren,
ducks, pigs
and pedestrians.
We had one of the best Chinese chows which I
ever eaten " E Tal E" (Italy to you)
Restaurent, and spent the night
the Company house.
Our traffic representative
explained that our
bedding had been rented for the occasion.
I wonder who from!
morning the weather was
bad again and we waited at
the barge on the
river for more weather reports.
While we were waiting - two
passengers and
three Chinese
- a corpse
floated by almost within reach.
Our Chinese fellow travelers
"Eye yah"!
turned a shade
or two whi ter.
Didn't like it too much ma myself.
The weather
got better and now we are approaching Shanghai
where
there will be plenty to do.
I am enclosing two photos,
of me alone
standing in front of the temple at Macao where
Cushing in 1044 signed the first treaty between the United States
and China.
The other is a picture taken with Mr. Gourley (American
Consul at Hongkong) in front of the gate
which separates
the Portuguese
Colony of Macao from China.
Note the soldiers in
the background -
is in Africa.
We are now within sight of the airport so I'll say good-bye
until another
chance to write.
As ever,
Km3
